item.title: Intro to Electronics/Arduino
item.dc:creator: canderson
item.content:encoded:
Becoming familiar with Arduino (including simple code examples).

The Electronics (or Getting to Know Your Microcontroller)

(assumes usage of the Arduino Uno) This is meant as a basic overview of the Uno. For a more comprehensive overview, see this page. The Uno is based on the ATmega328, the datasheet of which you can find here. Get used to looking for datasheets. They are generally published by the manufacturer as a complete resource for how a particular Integrated Circuit functions, containing things like detailed information regarding Current, Voltage, etc. features/requirements, as well as the role of each pin. Any time you are trying to build something that requires an IC you have not used before your first step should be to look for the datasheet. This is almost always accomplished via a simple Google search (example: ATmega328 datasheet).

Features of the Uno

• 14 digital input/output pins (6 of which can be used as PWM outputs) • 6 analog inputs • 16 MHz crystal oscillator • USB connection • Power jack (DC) • ICSP header • Reset button The Uno can be powered via USB or with an external power supply (batteries or an AC-DC power adapter). Take a look at the Voltage requirements: the arduino is manufactured to operate between 6 and 20 Volts. So, anything outside of the range could either damage the board (exceeding 20V) or cause unpredictable behavior (under 6V [the example they use on the page is a 5V power supply yielding unusual behavior]) and/or simply not provide enough current to the board in order for it to be operational. If you are wondering how the range of voltages is accomplished, it does so with a Voltage Regulator. A Voltage Regulator is kind of like a smart Voltage Divider: it will look at incoming V and scale up/down to a desired range. In other words, as long as you are sending the Arduino Voltage within the 6-20V range, the board will be fine. Arduino recommends sticking between 7-12 Volts, and I tend to either use the USB port, a 9V battery, or a small Voltage AC-DC power supply within these ranges (I rarely exceed 12V input). Right off the bat you need to focus on the following pins (all related to power): • VIN • 5V • 3V3 • GND VIN – This is the input V to the Arduino board when using an external power source. You can supply, or tap into, V on this pin. 5V – Outputs a regulated 5V from the board. Avoid plugging an external power supply directly into this pin, as it bypasses the regulator, and therefore could destroy your board. 3V3 – Get used to this kind of abbreviation. Sometimes the unit of measurement is used in place of a decimal point. So, this pin supplies 3.3V from the regulator. GND – Remember to complete your circuit by making sure power, and anything else, is grounded.

Input/Output

One of the cool things about the Arduino Uno is that each of the digital pins can function either as an input or output. We will talk about how to do this in more detail later, but for now, just keep that in mind. Each pin operates at 5V and can receive/provide a maximum of 40 mA. More specifically: • Serial: 0 (RX) and 1 (TX) - RX is used to receive serial data, TX is used to send it. • PWM: 3, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11 – Provide 8-bit Pulse Width Modulation output • LED 13 – your Arduino Uno has a built in LED tied to pin 13. Additionally, the Uno has 6 analog inputs (A0 through A5), measuring by default from Ground to 5V. Lastly, you should see the following: • AREF: A reference Voltage for the analog inputs. This gives a component something to compare to a changing Voltage for other purposes. • RESET: Resets the microcontroller by sending a LOW (off) message.

void setup() vs. void loop()

Whatever code is placed in void setup() will be called once immediately when the application starts. It will not be called again. Therefore, this is a good place to declare variables, pin modes, start using libraries, etc. The loop() function is called repeatedly from then on. So, any component of your code that accepts changing values (for example, monitoring live sensor input) should go here. Here is the basic structure for almost every Arduino program you will need to implement: 
void setup() {
// put your setup code here, to run once:

}

void loop() {
// put your main code here, to run repeatedly:

}
The lines of code that start with two forward slashes are ignored by the Arduino and are known as comments. You can use these to leave yourself notes, or to explain parts of your code to other users.

Blinking LED

int led = 13;

// the setup routine runs once when you press reset:
void setup() {
// initialize the digital pin as an output.
pinMode(led, OUTPUT);
}

// the loop routine runs over and over again forever:
void loop() {
digitalWrite(led, HIGH); // turn the LED on (HIGH is the voltage level)
delay(1000); // wait for a second
digitalWrite(led, LOW); // turn the LED off by making the voltage LOW
delay(1000); // wait for a second
}
We start by declaring a variable named “led” of data type int. Int is short for integer, or any whole number. This is a different data type than a float (floating point, or decimal number) or string (unicode text character), and Arduino needs to know ahead of time what type of data is going to be held in any variable. The equals sign is an assignment operator. It tells Arduino that the variable named led is assigned the value 13. This is different than the == sign, which is the way to test to see if some variable is a particular value. Next we have void setup() Here we set the pinMode. pinMode() allows us to set a particular pin as either an output or an input. In order to do this, we need to tell pinMode which pin we are referring to as well as whether it will be an input (INPUT) or output (OUTPUT). Since we already told the interpreter that the variable led has the value 13, we can just use “led” in the space of the first parameter (for pin number), and then the word OUTPUT (all caps) in the second parameter. As discussed earlier, void loop() runs repeatedly. We are alternating between two kinds of code in this example: digitalWrite, and delay. DigitalWrite() writes a HIGH or Low value to a digital pin. We can think of HIGH as “on” and LOW as “off,” but the more accurate way to imagine what is happening is that HIGH is the power source value (either 5V or 3.3V) and LOW is ground (or 0V). In the first line of code, we turn the LED on. delay() pauses the program for however many milliseconds one has entered into its parameter. If we did not have delay here, we would likely not see our LED turn on at all. So, here, the LED is turned on, and then the entire program is paused for 1 second. Hopefully the next two lines of code now make sense: the LED is turned off, and then the entire program is paused for another second, at which point the loop() function repeats. When using delay(), all other functions/processes happening in your program will be paused. In other words, nothing happens during a delay(). So, though this is fine for a simple blinking LED, if you were trying to control the time-flow of simultaneous functions at different intervals, you would want to use millis(). The Arduino website recommends avoiding the use of delay() unless you are only pausing the program for 10s of milliseconds, favoring millis() for more substantial, human-noticeable amounts of time.

Sensors

Most sensor input follows a similar setup. Let's start with a Potentiometer. You can think of this as having two ears and a nose. The nose is the output, the ears are inputs. The only thing that matters regarding which ear you use is which direction you turn the knob to increase/decrease resistance. So, for a pot, to interface with our Arduino: Nose to any input (example: A0) Ear 1 to ground Ear 2 to 5V or 3.3V Attach a potentiometer to your Arduino and copy the code below into a new window: 
/* Potentiometer testing sketch. */

int potPin = 0; // Nose of pot is connected to analog 0
int LEDpin = 11; // connect Red LED to pin 11 (PWM pin)
int potReading; // the analog reading from the Potentiometer
int LEDbrightness;

void setup(void) {
Serial.begin(9600); // We'll send debugging information via the Serial monitor
pinMode(LEDpin, OUTPUT);
}

void loop(void) {
potReading = analogRead(potPin);
Serial.print("Analog reading = ");
Serial.println(potReading);

// we'll need to change the range from the analog reading (0-1023) down to the range
// used by analogWrite (0-255) with map!

LEDbrightness = map(potReading, 0, 1023, 0, 255);

analogWrite(LEDpin, LEDbrightness);
Serial.print( "LED value = " );
Serial.println( LEDbrightness );
delay(10);
}
All of this should look more or less familiar, with the exception of Serial.begin(), etc. The Serial class is used for communication between Arduino and a computer. Serial enables you to do a lot of things, but in this case it is going to allow us to monitor the value of the potentiometer. We set the serial data rate in bits per second to start serial transmission. Generally, 9600 will be a perfectly fine BAUD rate to use (particularly when starting out). Serial.print/println() prints the incoming values from the potentiometer to the Serial Monitor. Lastly, we are mapping the incoming pot reading from 0 - 1023 to 0 - 255. Any time you need to change the data range of one variable to some other range and do not feel like doing the math, you can simply use map(). We can use this basic framework for most other sensor input, the only thing that will change is how you attach the sensor to the Arduino. Download the pdf here and try to use the above patch with other sensors. As an example: modifying out potentiometer code to utilize a flex sensor 
// Flex sensor test program

// Sensor pin - GND
// Sensor pin - Analog In 0, with 10K resistor to +5V

// INSTRUCTIONS:
// Upload this sketch to your Arduino, then activate the Serial Monitor
// (set the Serial Monitor to 9600 baud)

int LEDpin = 11; // connect Red LED to pin 11 (PWM pin)
int LEDbrightness;

void setup()
{
// initialize serial communications
Serial.begin(9600);
}

void loop()
{
int sensor, degrees;

// read the voltage from the voltage divider (sensor plus resistor)
sensor = analogRead(0);
degrees = map(sensor, 768, 853, 0, 90);

LEDbrightness = map( sensor, 768, 853, 0, 255 )l
analogWrite(LEDpin, LEDbrightness);

// print out the result
Serial.print("analog input: ");
Serial.print(sensor,DEC);
Serial.print(" degrees: ");
Serial.println(degrees,DEC);

// pause before taking the next reading
delay(10);
}

item.title: Data Tracking/Parsing, Pachube
item.dc:creator: canderson
item.content:encoded:
A tutorial covering data tracking techniques, different sensor usages, and connecting to the outside world. This workshop will pick up where workshop 1, functionality and usage of various sensors, left off. If you missed the first workshop, rough notes can be found here. Other resources for basic sensor application can be found at adafruit, arduino, and (specifically for the LM335 temperature sensor) here.

Data Tracking

(assumes that you have installed/configured your laptop/arduino for use with the NetLab ToolKit and have Flash) 1. Connect any sensor to your arduino, the arduino to your computer, and run the NetLab Hub and Flash 2. We are going to be working in ActionScript3, so remember to select a new AS3 file 3. Drag an AnalogIn widget onto the stage and, in properties, name it something like input0 4. Drag a ClipControl widget onto the stage 5. Select the rectangle tool and draw a rectangle somewhere on the stage. After doing this, control-click on the rectangle and choose "convert to symbol." A menu should pop up in which you can choose the registration (i.e. the point from which the symbol will move, let's start with the center point), name the object (example: clip1), and select "Movie Clip" in the Type field Before continuing, make sure that the rectangle moves when you use your sensor. If it does, move on to the next step. 6. Add a second ClipControl widget to the stage 7. Add an Insert object onto the stage. Name that object something like insert0 8. In the properties panel, make sure the second ClipControl is sending information to clip1, but that its input is set to insert0, and then run the file. The stage should look something like this: The rectangle should now move when there is a registered change on the sensor. 9. In order to actually test the data tracking function, press the record button (red circle) on the Insert widget and move the rectangle around. To stop recording, hit the record button again 10. Now press play on the Insert widget. You should see the rectangle move exactly as you moved it while recording. Exit out of the running version of the file and click on the Insert widget and then the properties panel. Here you can see the numerous options for the Insert object. Phil Van Allen (author of the NetLab Toolkit) summarizes the various options for the Insert object nicely here, so the following will be a light version of that page (and will skip some properties). -The Insert object defaults to looped playback of recorded values (though this can be toggled off). -The speed/rate of playback of recorded information defaults to 1, but if one wanted to track in real time and then playback much faster (for example), that could be achieved by increasing this number.

Clock vs. Value Change

Any data tracking deals ultimately with a question of priorities: time versus changing values. Though interrelated in any data tracking application, the emphasis on one over the other can have significant ramifications regarding the types of applications possible with your data. In certain situations, it is only going to be necessary to record data when the recorded value has changed (for example, tracking temperature), orienting tracking to an emphasis on the data and leaving time as a secondary value. On the other hand, there may be other situations in which it is important to record the current data value every, for example, five seconds whether or not the data has changed. This methodology privileges time over changing data value. What are some situations in which a regular, clock-like data tracking approach would be more or less appropriate than one where data is only recorded upon value change? How could changing orientations change the way one's data looks? The Insert widget allows for either orientation in the "recordSparse" parameter. If recordSparse is enabled, Insert will only store data when there is a value change. If recordSparse is not enabled, a data value will be recorded every x interval of time. One obvious benefit of keeping recordSparse on is the resulting .csv file will have substantially less data points than the amount generated otherwise. Nonetheless, if you are using a computer program to handle your csv file parsing, the amount of data points may not matter (with the exception of having a larger or smaller size file). Try tracking your sensor input both with recordSparse enabaled and without. What differences do you notice in playback?

CSV parsing

(assumes Processing has been installed on your computer) The Insert object will dump all of its recorded data into a .csv (comma separated value) file wherever your flash file is saved. Insert logs the following information in the csv file: data value, milliseconds since the beginning of the recording, date and time stamp, and name of the widget that is transmitting sensor input (recorded in that order). So, right off the bat, there are some questions to consider: do I only care about elapsed time since the beginning of data tracking, or the real-world date/time-stamp, or both? Additionally, am I looking at multiple data input streams (i.e. more than one sensor)? For the purposes of this example, we will assume the following: 1. the only time value we care about is the elapsed time, in ms, since the beginning of recording 2. the only other information we will look at is data value 3. there is only one input 4. we would like to pair any recorded time with its corresponding data value for each line in the csv file automatically So, in order to be able to process this data automatically, there are a few things that our computer program will need to do: 1. load our csv file into an array in such a manner that each line is a separate item 2. for each line, split the values whenever there is a comma (in other words, each line will now have four items) 3. only pay attention to the value and time items on each line 4. for each line, keep the appropriate value and time pairs together, and store them in an array where one can access either the value or time field (or both) Copy/paste the following into a Processing window: Prior to running the code, you need to open your Processing sketch file and put the csv file (produced by the Insert object) into a folder named "data" (you will need to create this folder). Here is how the program works: 1. declare an array named data that will store Strings 2. declare a two-dimensional array called dataPairs that will store Integers 3. arbitrarily create a window (so we have an easy way to check to see if something went wrong) 4. create the array named data. 5. perform the function loadData(); 6. perform the function printStoredData(); loadData() 1. create an array named csv which will hold Strings, and fill it with the information from our csv file 2. create the array dataPairs. Its first dimension will be as long as the number of lines in our csv file (loadStrings automatically separates each line as its own item...). The second dimension will only be two positions long. 3. the for() loop: first it creates an array named fileData, which will store Strings, and makes a new line for each item (split by commas). then it stores the data value from line 0 (the first time) in position 1 of the second dimension of the array, and the time in position 2. this is repeated for each line of the csv file until i is no longer less than the length of the csv file. notice that prior to storing the value and time information to the array each is converted to an integer (called int casting). This is necessary because the csv file was initially loaded into an array as a String, meaning the information would not be usable as numbers until explicitly changed to int or float. printStoredData() We only need to pay attention to the length of the first dimension since we know that the second dimension will never be more than two positions (because the second dimension is only value-time pairs). That being the case, this for() loop will print the value and time pairs for each line in the newly formatted dataPairs array. Pretty simple. If you wanted to use that information for other things, just keep in mind that you use the first dimension to specify which value-time pair, and the second dimension to specify whether you are referring to the value or the time. For example, dataPairs[ 1 ][ 0 ] would return the value field for the second data point. dataPairs[ 1 ][ 1 ] would return the time field for the same data point. Changing the 1 in the first dimension to another number would select a different data point.

Pachube

Pachube is an excellent example of a community of data streams. Since Pachube was treated more as a case-study, or a possible point of investigation, the following are links to various aspects of Pachube which were discussed at the end of the workshop. Pachube's home. The Pachube docs. A step-by-step guide for interfacing arduino and Pachube (either to broadcast or to receive data). Pachube's blog has lots of nice examples of the types of conversations, and design projects, going on in the Pachube community.

item.title: Printing on the MDP Bukobot - Essentials
item.dc:creator: vanallen
item.content:encoded:
Step by step instructions below.

Overview

Printing objects (we call them "parts") on the Bukobot is fairly easy, and is somewhat similar to using the laser cutter. You need to find or create the 3D model of your part and export it in the STL format. Then you import that model into the software that controls the Bukobot 3D printer, which is called Repetier. [caption id="attachment_125" align="alignright" width="300"] Fused deposition modeling:
1 – nozzle ejecting molten plastic
2 – deposited material (modeled part)
3 – controlled movable table.
Diagram from Wikipedia.[/caption] After configuring Repetier for the material type and printing resolution, you must slice the part. Our Bukobot uses the additive technology called Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM), where layers of material are laid down to create the part. Slicing cuts the 3D part into a series of layers that are extruded onto the printer platform, one at a time, building the part from bottom to top.

Parts are Usually Hollow

Note also that to save material and print faster, the parts are not printed as complete solids. Instead, the interior of the parts are normally printed in a honeycomb fashion, which leaves them mostly hollow.

Printing Materials

The Bukobot printer can print with either PLA or ABS material. For most cases, we recommend PLA. Comparison of PLA and ABS here.
  • PLA - Made from plants, is more environmentally friendly, and is easier to work with than ABS. PLA is more rigid but also more brittle than ABS, and does not require the printer platform to be heated.
  • ABS - Petroleum based, higher melting point, and is easier to work with (e.g. sanding, machining, etc.) after the part is printed. More pliable than PLA, but not as strong.

Step by Step Instructions

  1. Create or get the 3D part
    1. Get an open-source 3D model from Thingiverse.com or other source
    2. OR design a part from scratch or modify an existing part you find
      1. Options: tinkercad (free, web based), FormZ (free to students), SolidWorks (PC only), Sketchup, Open SCAD (create models by programming), Autodesk 123D Design
      2. Export the part as an STL file, using millimeters (mm) as your measurement unit
  2. Power up Bukobot and computer
    1. Login to the computer at the Bukobot workstation and open Repetier (on the left of the OS X toolbar), which is the software that runs the printer
    2. Plug in the Bukobot printer to power it on
    3. In Repetier, click on the Connect button to establish communication with the printer
  3. Set up the part in Repetier
    1. Put your .STL file on the Bukobot computer
    2. Select the Object Placement tab in the upper right
    3. Select Add STL File in the panel on the lower right
    4. Optionally adjust the size/position of the part
      1. Scale - You can adjust the size of the part if necessary by editing the Scale X amount to be larger than 1 to increase, or less than 1 to decrease the scale (have the "Lock Aspect Ratio box checked). For example, if your part uses inches, it will import very small.
      2. Rotate  - You may need to rotate the part so it can print best. For example, if a part has openings on the bottom that close at the top, you should turn it upside down so the closed part is printed first as a foundation for the openings. Do this by putting 180 in the Y Rotate field (note that the part will now be below the printer platform surface - see next step)
      3. Center - Click on Center Object in panel on the lower right to ensure the part is resting on the surface of the platform and centered
  4. Set the Slicer settings - we use Slic3r
    1. Select the Slicer tab in the upper right
    2. Select the appropriate Print Settings from the drop down. If this is your first print of the object or you are inexperienced, select the 0.3 setting which is the fastest, but lowest resolution
    3. Select the appropriate Filament Settings for Extruder 1 from the drop down. This depends on the material you are printing with.
  5. Slice the part
    1. Clicking on Slice with Slic3r in the Object Placement panel
    2. Note any errors displayed in the log at the bottom
    3. Note also the estimate of how much material is needed in millimeters (mm) and make sure that you have enough length on the spool to complete your part
  6. Check the printer calibration
    1. Switch to the Print Panel
    2. One at a time, click on the Home button for each X,Y,Z axis and make sure the print head ends up in the front left of the platform, with the head just barely touching the platform
    3. If the printer is not properly calibrated, check with Casey or Phil, and also have a look at the Pre-Flight Bukobot page for information about proper calibration
  7. Print the part
    1. Ensure you have material loaded in the print head with sufficient length to complete your part
    2. Click the Run button to start the print job, noting the estimated print time at the very bottom of the screen (this is a very rough estimate and may be longer or shorter than the actual print time, depending on the characteristics of the part)
    3. Switch the display to Temperature Curve and wait until the print head (and platform if heated) temperature gets to the proper temperature
    4. The printer will start by printing a thin perimeter line around where the part will be printed - this helps get the material flow correct before the real printing begins
    5. Once the part starts printing, monitor for a few minutes to make sure everything is working correctly - if anything goes badly wrong, you can always click on the Emergency Stop button in the upper right. Of if you just want to stop the part, you can click on Kill Job.
    6. In the log section of Repetier at the bottom of the window, you can see which layer is currently being printed, out of the total layers, as well as the estimated time to completion.
    7. Once the print job finishes, the printer should move the head out of the way, and the print head should cool off. Check the Temperature Curve display to make sure the temperature is dropping.
    8. If you aren't making any other parts, unplug the Bukobot printer.
  8. Remove the part
    1. The part will likely be stuck to the blue painters tape. To get it off, you'll need to wedge something under it to break it free from the platform.
    2. Try using the black plastic wedge we have in the desk drawer. Kind of wiggle the sharp end around the edges of the part until it breaks free
  9. Clean up the part
    1. There will almost always be some "flash" or bits of extra plastic on the edges of the part, left over from the printing process
    2. Use a small file or sandpaper to remove this flash, and clean up the part
    3. If your part has a hole in it, you may need to use a reamer to clean out the hole and enlarge it to be the right diameter

item.title: Laser Cutting Guidelines
item.dc:creator: canderson

item.title: CorelDRAW X6 Layout for Laser Cutting
item.dc:creator: canderson

item.title: Laser Cutting Guidelines
item.dc:creator: cmccrae
item.content:encoded:
Exporting from Illustrator

[caption id="attachment_283" align="alignright" width="270"] Save as Illustrator CS[/caption] Use only RGB format and be sure your art fits inside the Artboard. Objects must be limited to less than seven basic colors, and text must be converted to paths (freehand) or outlines (Illustrator). Maximum file size is 4 megabytes. Remember to keep it simple! This will help avoid problems.
  1. Place all objects on a single layer
  2. File > Save As… > filename.ai  - Keep the .ai format
  3. Version > Illustrator CS (Legacy format)
 

Exporting from SolidWorks/AutoCAD

  1. File > Save As Drawing
  2. Save out as .DXF and .DWG (one format sometimes does not work)
 

Importing into Corel Draw & Formatting Your File

[caption id="attachment_238" align="alignright" width="280"] Left click for Fill, right click for Outline[/caption]
  1. File > New (Always make a new document)
  2. File > Import 
  3. For .DXF and .DWG files, check "Auto Reduce Nodes"
  4.  An angle icon will appear; click once
  5. Check for double lines (Tools > Object manger)
  6. Convert line widths to 'hairline'
  7. Change artwork to ULS color swatches
  8. Left click for FILL, right click OUTLINE
 

Focusing the Laser Cutter

[caption id="attachment_211" align="aligncenter" width="603"] The Laser Control Panel[/caption]
  1. Turn the exhaust system and the machine on
  2. Press the "Z" button
  3. Place the focus tool on the top surface of your material. Always place material shiny side down. 
  4. Raise or lower the up/down triangle buttons until the edge of the focuser sits against the edge of the laser carriage.
  5. Press the 'select' button to change the climbing increments (.1 to .01)
  6. Press the "Z" button (to send the carriage 'home')
   

The Print Menu

  1. Always do a small test cut!
  2. File > Print (not print preview)
  3. Click the SELECTION option (look at the print preview window)
  4. Click on the PROPERTIES button
  5. Change your Pen Mode to VECT or RAST (not 'VECT/RAST')
  6. Click and highlight the %Power and %Speed (change one color at a time)
  7. Use the settings for that particular laser
  8. click the SET button
  9. click OK
  10. click PRINT

 

In Case of Fire

In case of flame or fire, click PAUSE (RESUME button will continue from where you paused)
  1. Lift lid
  2. Eject card
  3. Water bottle
  4. Extinguisher

  [caption id="attachment_282" align="alignright" width="260"] Don't use the Copy Center card. Laser Cards can be purchased at the Tool Crib.[/caption]

Laser Cards & Thumb Drives

The laser cutters operate on a card reader system, similar to a copy machine. Laser Cards can be purchased at the Tool Crib for $13 ($1 cost of card, $12 cutting time).
  • Do not use the Copy Center card
  • Write your name on the "Laser Card" with a permanent marker
  • Title your thumb drive with your ID number and make a file with your contact information on your thumb drive in case you leave it in the lab.

Laser Cutting Policies

  • Do not leave machine unattended while cutting. If you do so, you will be fined $100 and your work will be removed.
  • Come prepared and ready to cut. Do not prepare artwork on the computers in the Laser Lab. 
  • If there are others waiting, there will be a 30-minute work period per student. The 30-minute period begins when you are seated.
  • If there are others using the laser cutter, add your name to the sign up sheet.
  • Do not remove any hardware from the machines: screws, lenses, fixtures, beds, rulers, side doors, rotary axis, etc. Please ask for assistance.
  • Preferred material: acrylic (up to 3/8") plywood (up to 1/8", paper, cardboard, leather, and Masonite. Refer to materials charts or ask about properties of something you'd like to cut.
  • Do not cut any of the following material: vinyl, lexan, linoleum, hard woods (mahogany), styrene, pac, ABS plastic, 1/4" plywood, or metal.
  • Keep all work areas clean.
  • Make sure that you are using the appropriate page layout: Laser32, Laser24, or Epilog. (18x32, 18x24, 36x24)
  • Use only PC formatted storage devices. Use the network to/from various labs, burn files to a CD, or email them to yourself.
  • Be wary of iPods, using someone else's thumb drive, and MAC-only formatted drives.
